channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hong Kong Police Clear Part of Protest Camp
item.description: Hundreds of police officers assembled to enforce a court injunction demanding that protesters stop blocking Argyle Street in Mong Kok.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG

item.title: 7 Students of Jailed Economist Are Put on Trial in Western China
item.description: The seven studied at Minzu University of China under Ilham Tohti, an ethnic Uighur who was convicted of separatism in September and received a life sentence.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: America Musn’t Neglect Its Nukes
item.description: The country faces new threats and needs a strong nuclear deterrent more than ever.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ELBRIDGE COLBY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Proposed Regulations Aim to Clamp Down on Smoking in China
item.description: Hundreds of millions of people who smoke in China may face much tougher rules in the future, as draft regulations banning smoking in all indoor public places have been unveiled.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons smoking in a Beijing restaurant. Under draft regulations, smoking in indoor public places would become illegal throughout China.

item.title: Memo From Melilla: At Spanish Enclave, a Debate Over What Makes a Border
item.description: Spanish authorities, struggling to secure the borders to their enclaves in Africa, are facing a new legal challenge over the position of border fences.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Musical Ode to Xi Jinping and His Wife Goes Viral
item.description: “Xi Dada Loves Peng Mama” and its accompanying video were inspired by images of China’s top couple together in recent news coverage, the song’s lyricist said.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Hacker Disrupts Government Websites in Canada
item.description: A gyrating banana greeted many visiting the pages for Parliament, the Supreme Court, the city of Ottawa and the Ottawa and Toronto police forces.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: War Tribunal Issues a Death Sentence
item.description: A special tribunal on Monday sentenced a man to death for his role in mass killings during Bangladesh’s 1971 independence war.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: 77 Arrested in Connection With Attack
item.description: Saudi Arabia said Monday that it had arrested 77 people linked to what it called a terrorist attack that killed seven people this month in the eastern part of the country.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Turkish President Says Women Shouldn’t Be Considered Equals
item.description: At an international conference on justice and rights, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Monday said that women should not be regarded as equal to men and condemned feminists for rejecting motherhood.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Pact Tightens Russian Ties With Abkhazia
item.description: The accord with the breakaway region of Georgia comes at a time of deep apprehension in the West over Russia’s expansionist aspirations.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: A Nuclear Deal for U.S. and Iran Slips Away Again
item.description: Negotiations carried on in secret for months, but despite a thaw between the governments’ top envoys, the end result is only another extension.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER, MICHAEL R. GORDON and PETER BAKER.
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, gestures toward Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif while posing with other diplomats Monday during their meeting in Vienna.

item.title: World Briefing: New Strain of Bird Flu Prompts a Warning for Farmers
item.description: A new, lethal strain of bird flu detected this month on poultry farms in Britain and the Netherlands has now been reported in Germany, among both domesticated birds and a wild bird, international agriculture authorities said Monday.
item.category: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Democratic Republic of Congo: Rebels Kill Dozens
item.description: The attack took place near Beni in North Kivu Province, where a mainly Ugandan rebel group has been blamed for killing more than 200 civilians since October.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Hagel Resigns Under Pressure as Global Crises Test Pentagon
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s passivity and lack of support in President Obama’s inner circle proved too much for an administration that found itself back on a war footing.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel at a news conference Monday with President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

item.title: With No Immediate Prospect of Sanctions Relief for Iranians, Support for President Slips
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has in the eyes of many failed to deliver on pledges to get sanctions lifted, provide more freedoms and improve the economy.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: U.S. and Allies Extend Iran Nuclear Talks by 7 Months
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry says “new ideas surfaced,” as a temporary agreement remains in place and Iran gets $5 billion more in sanctions relief.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Mr. Kerry with Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif of Iran on Monday in Vienna.

item.title: News Analysis: A Shake-Up Stops at One
item.description: The departure of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is part of a shake-up that does not address deeper doubts about the administration’s capacity to deal with a series of global crises.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s national security adviser.

item.title: As Bombing Toll Rises, Afghan Villagers Direct Anger at Government
item.description: Villagers of Yahya Khel, where a bomber killed 61 people Sunday, expressed anger at the Taliban but also at a national government they felt had offered them little.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers from Yahya Khel district, where a suicide bomber killed dozens on Sunday, gathered to listen to Abdullah Abdullah, Afghanistan’s chief executive.

item.title: Open Source: Video Analysis of Fatal West Bank Shooting Said to Implicate Israeli Officer
item.description: Analysis of video of the May shooting suggested that the officer was to blame, the boy’s father and an Israeli who reconstructed the shooting said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: An Israeli border police officer was escorted to a hearing in Jerusalem after he was arrested on suspicion of involvement in the fatal shooting of two Palestinian teenagers in the West Bank in May.

item.title: Report Faults Care of Peace Corps Volunteer
item.description: The Peace Corps inspector general cited “cascading delays and failures in treatment” as a factor in the death in 2013 of Nick Castle, a volunteer who fell gravely ill in China.
item.dc:creator: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG
item.media:description: Nick Castle, a 2012 graduate of the University of California, Berkeley.

item.title: Bombs Hit Sole Civilian Airport in Libyan Capital
item.description: Commanders from Operation Dignity said they ordered the strikes because the airport and the capital had fallen under the control of the rival coalition Libya Dawn.
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Leading Surgeon Is Accused of Misconduct in Experimental Transplant Operations
item.description: A doctor who is considered a pioneer in the field of regenerative medicine has denied carrying out innovative operations without ethical approvals.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Kunstmuseum Bern Obtains Trove From Gurlitt Collection
item.description: In agreeing to take the gift of more than 1,000 works, the Kunstmuseum Bern said it would ensure that any seized art in the trove was returned to its rightful owner.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: “Street Tram,” by Bernhard Kretschmar, is one of the works in the trove that Cornelius Gurlitt kept for years in his Munich apartment.

item.title: Three Arabs Are Arrested in Stabbings in Jerusalem
item.description: The police said they were investigating the stabbings as a possible terrorist attack that extended violence that has roiled the city for a month.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
